channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: A 'Hot Zone' In The Brain May Reveal When, And Even What, We Dream
item.description: April 10, 2017 - When people have dreams, an area near the back of the brain seems to wake up. And specific patterns of brain activity in that area can even reveal what we're dreaming about.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 10, 2017 - When people have dreams, an area near the back of the brain seems to wake up. And specific patterns of brain activity in that area can even reveal what we're dreaming about. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/10/523262108/a-hot-zone-in-the-brain-may-reveal-when-and-even-what-we-dream

item.title: Natural Gas Plant Makes A Play For Coal's Market, Using 'Clean' Technology
item.description: April 10, 2017 - The idea behind "clean coal" is technology that would capture for reuse most of the carbon dioxide emitted by coal-burning power plants. Entrepreneurs aim to use similar tech to clean natural gas.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 10, 2017 - The idea behind "clean coal" is technology that would capture for reuse most of the carbon dioxide emitted by coal-burning power plants. Entrepreneurs aim to use similar tech to clean natural gas. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/07/522662776/natural-gas-plant-makes-a-play-for-coals-market-using-clean-technology

item.title: Great Barrier Reef Hit By Bleaching For The Second Year In A Row
item.description: April 10, 2017 - Scientists say severe bleaching events have happened three other times in the past 20 years — but never in consecutive years. They fear that prolonged stress could kill the corals.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 10, 2017 - Scientists say severe bleaching events have happened three other times in the past 20 years — but never in consecutive years. They fear that prolonged stress could kill the corals. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/10/523254085/great-barrier-reef-hit-by-bleaching-for-the-second-year-in-a-row

item.title: Drugs That Work In Mice Often Fail When Tried In People
item.description: April 10, 2017 - Most potential new drugs don't work when tested in people. It's a major disappointment and it drives up the cost of developing new drugs. One big reason is the use of animals in medical research.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 10, 2017 - Most potential new drugs don't work when tested in people. It's a major disappointment and it drives up the cost of developing new drugs. One big reason is the use of animals in medical research. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/10/522775456/drugs-that-work-in-mice-often-fail-when-tried-in-people

item.title: A Mountain Lion Kitten Is Found, Leading To Excitement And Concern
item.description: April 9, 2017 - A mountain lion kitten was found in the Santa Monica Mountains, just outside Los Angeles. Biologists are excited to see new kittens being born but are concerned about inbreeding.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 9, 2017 - A mountain lion kitten was found in the Santa Monica Mountains, just outside Los Angeles. Biologists are excited to see new kittens being born but are concerned about inbreeding. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/09/523163935/a-mountain-lion-kitten-is-found-leading-to-excitement-and-concern

item.title: It Sounds Like Science Fiction But ... It's A Cliché
item.description:
April 9, 2017 - The Internet is full of science fiction becoming science fact. NPR Science Editor Geoff Brumfiel is ready to make a stand. Sort of.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/04/09/523030282/it-sounds-like-science-fiction-but-its-a-clich
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 9, 2017 - The Internet is full of science fiction becoming science fact. NPR Science Editor Geoff Brumfiel is ready to make a stand. Sort of. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/09/523030282/it-sounds-like-science-fiction-but-its-a-clich

item.title: How Playing Tetris Tames The Trauma Of A Car Crash
item.description: April 9, 2017 - Researchers were able to dial down painful recollections of a car crash by having people play the video game Tetris while in the emergency room. The technique makes use of the malleability of memory.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 9, 2017 - Researchers were able to dial down painful recollections of a car crash by having people play the video game Tetris while in the emergency room. The technique makes use of the malleability of memory. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/09/523011446/how-playing-tetris-tames-the-trauma-of-a-car-crash

item.title: VIDEO: Despite The Risks, Morphine Can Offer Hope
item.description: April 8, 2017 - Morphine, like other opiates, is controversial. It poses risks. But for some patients, like a man in India who's profiled in a short documentary, the painkiller offers hope.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 8, 2017 - Morphine, like other opiates, is controversial. It poses risks. But for some patients, like a man in India who's profiled in a short documentary, the painkiller offers hope. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/08/522994283/video-despite-the-risks-morphine-can-offer-hope

item.title: When Gluten Is The Villain, Could A Common Virus Be The Trigger?
item.description: April 8, 2017 - About 30 percent of Americans are predisposed to celiac disease, but only 1 percent get the disease. A new study finds that a common virus may play a role in determining who gets the disease.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 8, 2017 - About 30 percent of Americans are predisposed to celiac disease, but only 1 percent get the disease. A new study finds that a common virus may play a role in determining who gets the disease. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/08/523002516/when-gluten-is-the-villain-could-a-common-virus-be-the-trigger

item.title: A Baby With 3 Genetic Parents Seems Healthy, But Questions Remain
item.description: April 8, 2017 - A baby who was conceived through an experimental procedure designed to prevent a deadly disease appears to be healthy. But some potentially defective DNA remains. Will it affect his health long term?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 8, 2017 - A baby who was conceived through an experimental procedure designed to prevent a deadly disease appears to be healthy. But some potentially defective DNA remains. Will it affect his health long term? http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/08/523020895/a-baby-with-3-genetic-parents-seems-healthy-but-questions-remain

item.title: Michigan's Tart Cherry Orchards Struggle To Cope With Erratic Spring Weather
item.description: April 7, 2017 - An unpredictable spring this year unnerved tart cherry growers in Michigan, because these cherry trees are especially vulnerable to extreme weather shifts made more likely by climate change.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 7, 2017 - An unpredictable spring this year unnerved tart cherry growers in Michigan, because these cherry trees are especially vulnerable to extreme weather shifts made more likely by climate change. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/07/523004370/michigans-tart-cherry-orchards-struggle-to-cope-with-erratic-spring-weather

item.title: Dalia Mogahed: How Does Speaking Up Change Minds?
item.description: April 7, 2017 - After 9/11, Dalia Mogahed saw an increase in negative perceptions of Muslims in the media, so she made it her job to speak up for her faith and fight prejudice with better understanding.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 7, 2017 - After 9/11, Dalia Mogahed saw an increase in negative perceptions of Muslims in the media, so she made it her job to speak up for her faith and fight prejudice with better understanding. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/07/522859280/dalia-mogahed-how-does-speaking-up-change-minds

item.title: James Hansen: What Makes A Scientist Take A Stand?
item.description: April 7, 2017 - When James Hansen spoke up about climate change in the 1980s, he risked the loss of his job and reputation. But, he says, it was worth it — because he could not be silent about something so important.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 7, 2017 - When James Hansen spoke up about climate change in the 1980s, he risked the loss of his job and reputation. But, he says, it was worth it — because he could not be silent about something so important. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/07/522856713/james-hansen-what-makes-a-scientist-take-a-stand

item.title: Adam Galinsky: What Drives Us To Speak Up?
item.description: April 7, 2017 - Social psychologist Adam Galinsky studies why it's so daunting to speak up — and what can help. He says the most powerful factor that compels us to take that risk is "moral conviction."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 7, 2017 - Social psychologist Adam Galinsky studies why it's so daunting to speak up — and what can help. He says the most powerful factor that compels us to take that risk is "moral conviction." http://www.npr.org/2017/04/07/522857511/adam-galinksy-what-drives-us-to-speak-up

item.title: Bison Or Brian? From A Calorie Perspective, Cannibalism Didn't Pay For Paleo Humans
item.description: April 6, 2017 - Archaeological records show ancient humans sometimes ate each other. A new study suggests that hunting and eating other humans cost too much effort to be a regular thing. So why'd they do it?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 6, 2017 - Archaeological records show ancient humans sometimes ate each other. A new study suggests that hunting and eating other humans cost too much effort to be a regular thing. So why'd they do it? http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/06/522880018/what-s-the-dietary-value-of-a-human
